text: 10 years ago my life changed forever
when i downloaded ableton since then
i've personally used ableton to get over
100 million streams tour the world as an
artist and after over a decade of
experience i have some tips tricks and
wisdom to transform the way that you
make music and now you don't have to
spend the next 10 years learning what i
learned and instead you can learn it all
in like 10 minutes all of these tips
were huge breakthrough moments for me
personally so make sure that you watch
all of them because you don't want to
miss out on that breakthrough moment in
your own life this video could actually
change the way you make music and change
your life because each of these 10 tips
did that for me and just as a little
side note there's a pretty long free
trial for ableton so if you don't have
it yet you can still watch this video
decide if you want to try it out and
then go for that free trial okay let's
get started my first tip is to have a
folder dedicated to sessions when i
first started working in ableton i made
the mistake of saving all my sessions in
the same project folder because i didn't
understand the way ableton structures
things so make a new folder on your
computer just for sessions and save each
song as a project in that folder let me
show you exactly what i mean okay so
let's say you just open up a new session
you can either start a little bit on
something but i like saving right out of
the gate just to make sure that i'm not
going to lose anything so go ahead and
go to file save live set as and then
make sure you have a specific folder for
ableton sessions created mine's usually
just called sessions i made this one
called ableton sessions as an example so
you're just going to go into that folder
and save your project and then click
save
now if we go into the finder and we go
into that folder you'll see the project
saved with a session folder in it you
want to make sure all of your songs have
their own project folder and not just
their own session folder so the project
folder says project next to it and the
session folder says als now one more
quick tip is you'll also want to collect
all and save so all the sounds and
samples that you have for this project
are inside this project folder so let's
go back into ableton and let's assume
that i've got a song here and i've got a
bunch of samples that i dragged in and i
want to make sure that if i share this
project with anyone else that all these
little clips are going to be in that
project folder i just go up here and go
to file and click collect all and save
now usually i just make sure these first
three say yes but you can make them all
say yes just in case and then just click
ok and now everything is collected in
that project folder if we go back to
that folder in the finder you'll see
that there's some new folders that
ableton created for example in the
samples folder we have all those clips
that we just dragged in this is such a
good way to stay organized and to make
sure that you're never missing any clips
which is such a headache when it happens
my second tip is to put a limiter on
your master channel and focus on mixing
instead of mastering a friend of mine
who works with people like skrillex zed
and lady gaga gave me this tip a few
years back i used to focus so much on
the perfect mastering chain and
unfortunately i relied on that to fix my
mix the reality is you should just put a
transparent limiter on your master
channel and just focus on getting the
best mix possible i personally use the
l2 limiter from fabfilter on the almost
clipping preset this is what it looks
like if you want to copy the settings
you could just pause it right now this
tip will allow you to get the cleanest
mix and the loudest master while being
able to maintain dynamics this tip has
actually made such a big impact on the
quality of my music that i can tell the
difference between everything i made
before it and after it listening back it
really did change my life so i would
highly recommend that you at least try
it out for a little bit and see if your
mixes go up in quality and clarity my
third tip is to use ping pong delay to
widen sounds and use utility to make
sounds more narrow this one is a little
bit more simple but it goes a long way
for production and mixing so let me show
you exactly how i do this okay so here i
have some vocals for a song i made
called get even i was able to utilize
this delay technique on one of the
returns that i was sending the vocal to
this is what the vocal sounds like just
by itself just give me a
chance to get even
then i sent that vocal to this chain
with little altar boy kind of adjusting
the formant and then i use this delay
trick to widen things and really make it
interesting let me show you what the
effect sounds like just give me a
chance to get even
it's kind of like a double that's super
wide with a really cool vocal tone slash
timbre but the whitening is what makes
the effect let me turn off the delay to
show you the difference just give me a
chance to get
it's still cool but it's not nearly as
interesting using this delay trick to
widen something in the mix just makes it
more interesting and it sounds more
stereo and more developed and just more
professional so if you want to make
something wider in the mix all you have
to do is just go over here to delay drag
it onto the track that you want to
effect go ahead and unlink these
change them both to time
and then set them to different times i
would say anywhere lower than about 30
milliseconds so we can do 27 over here
and we can do about 8 over here but
really it doesn't matter that much what
the numbers are as long as they're
different because all this delay is
doing is playing the same sound through
the left side and the right side but
just at slightly different times and
that makes your ears think that the
sound is super wide it's kind of a cool
little trick that you're playing on your
brain also make sure to turn your
feedback all the way down and turn your
dry wet all the way up now let's say
that the sound is too wide and we want
to kind of bring it in a little bit and
make it more in the center of the mix
well that's super easy all we have to do
is just drag on utility and play with
this with function right here just give
me a
chance to get even
all of a sudden it's in the middle of
the mix now and we can even make it
fully mono if we click on this or let's
say we're making some crazy dubstep and
we just want the sub bass to be mono we
can click this base mono feature and
this makes it so everything below this
frequency becomes mono kind of a cool
little novelty thing but anyway now you
know how to make things wider in the mix
and you know how to bring things into
the middle both of which are very
important for professional sounding
music my fourth tip is to use the sends
and returns for adding effects on vocals
in ableton it's very intuitive to drag
effects directly onto the tracks and i
would recommend this for 90 of the time
but specifically with vocals you'll want
to use the sends and returns for effects
like reverb and delay on your vocals
when you use this system instead of
putting reverb and delay directly on the
vocal channel you get 100 of the dry
vocal signal with the reverb and delay
on top of it this will give you a clean
professional sound and keep your vocals
really up front and present in the mix
just like they sound on professional
records let me show you what i mean okay
so here we have the vocal and this is
without it sending to anything this is
just the dry vocal lost in
outer space now let's say we want to add
some reverb to this we can just turn up
the send channel right here and that's
going to send this vocal all the way
down here to this channel which has some
reverb on it right here what this does
is it allows the vocal to come through
completely dry and then it puts reverb
on top of it instead of if we just do a
reverb like this at the end of the vocal
and play with the dry wet because every
time we're turning the wet up we're
actually making the dry vocal signal
come down in the mix and the reverb go
up but we want to be able to control the
reverb separately so this way we can
decide exactly how much reverb is on top
of the vocal while keeping all of that
amazing clear dry vocal signal right
where we want it so here's that same
vocal with a little reverb on it lost in
outer space
and how about we add a little delay too
[Music]
this is a great way to add effects to
anything the song also has a really cool
vocoder in it
and then these chords are really cool
too
[Music]
okay i'm getting carried away let's move
on my fifth tip is to utilize eq on
effects what i mean is when you're
sending things like vocals to a reverb
return or delay you can actually eq the
effect itself this is something i hear
pros including myself do all the time to
take production to the next level let's
go ahead and see this tip in action all
right so this vocal is sending to this
reverb and this delay and all i've done
is on the return tracks where the reverb
is i put an eq after the reverb and
scooped out a bunch of these low
frequencies that we don't need as well
as a bunch of these high frequencies now
if we play you can see some of these low
frequencies
now this way we can carve out exactly
what we want the reverb to sound like if
we look at the delay i did the exact
same thing here
and without this reverb we just allow a
bit too much coming through here and
coming through up here and it would
cause the delay and the reverb to kind
of take up too much space in the mix and
be too distracting this is a really good
way to hone in the exact sound you want
and another great way to sound
professional my sixth and potentially
most important tip is to mix as you go
it's helpful to mix as you produce at
least a little bit so you can keep
everything sounding clean and
professional and there isn't this huge
difference between when your song is
done being produced and then when it's
mixed and mastered i personally mix as i
go and leave that limiter on the master
channel remember from tip number two and
then when i'm done producing a song it's
basically mixed already too then i just
have to make a couple tweaks here and
there and make sure that it's loud
enough and i'm done that's it it's so
much easier than having to send it out
for mixing and then for mastering and
then going back and forth with notes and
all that like what if i want to make one
small change to the production then i
have to send it out all over again and
it's just a huge headache the mix as you
go method will save you time improve
your ability to mix and bring your ideas
to life and give you better mixes over
time also if you learn to mix your own
music you'll save so much money in the
long run you'll also have more creative
freedom and you won't depend on other
people to get your music finished and to
be fair this is still a good habit even
if you're sending your songs out to be
mixed because all of your tracks will be
more cleaned up it'll be closer to the
way you want the finished product to
sound and it'll also give the mixing
engineer a head start by providing him
with more of a direction to go in in
terms of mixing the track a small
example of mixing as you go is eq'ing
sub frequencies out of tracks that don't
need them let's jump into ableton so i
can demonstrate so if we go through a
finished song of mine almost every track
that you click on will have an eq
scooping out unnecessary low end most
sounds don't have any information we
need up to about 80 hertz and a lot of
them even up to about 100 hertz so for
example for the shaker we don't need any
of this information down here it's not
adding anything to the song it's not
improving the mix it's just taking up
space so instead of waiting for a mixing
engineer to take out all this
unnecessary stuff i could just mix as i
go and clean it up and as i do that i'll
hear the song back it'll sound better
and i'll be more inspired to keep going
and in turn i'll make more music i'll
get better making music and i hope
you're starting to realize why mixing as
you go can be such a helpful tool real
quick there's another string noise here
and i put an eq on it getting rid of
some of this low end stuff that we
didn't need and even a little bit of
high end because i wanted to kind of
tuck these strings back in the mix but
it's just another example of scooping
out some of these sub frequencies that
really aren't doing us any favors okay
so mix as you go my seventh tip is to
utilize audio effects racks and
instrument racks it sounds kind of
complicated but it's actually super
simple this is a huge time saver that i
wish i used more when i was first
starting out let's say you spend hours
getting the perfect effect chain for
your vocals well you can actually save
this chain as an audio effects rack in
ableton so you don't have to recreate it
every single time you want to apply it
to a vocal track you can also use this
for instruments as well as just saving
presets for effects in general let me
show you exactly what i'm talking about
and how you can potentially save hours
of tedious work okay so let's say we got
the perfect effects chain we love the
way that these strings sound and we want
to be able to use this effects chain
over and over we can just click on the
first effect then hold shift and click
on the last effect to highlight all the
effects and then we just press command g
and this is going to group them together
in an audio effects rack so now what we
do is we click this little symbol right
here it's going to bring up this little
save icon and now we can click on it and
we can save it as our super string
effects and press enter and now anytime
we want to use the string effect we
could just drag this onto the channel
and all the plugins will appear with all
the presets and everything ready to go
this has saved me so much time over the
years it's also worth mentioning that
you can do this with an instrument so
let's say that we love this midi bass
sound
so to do that all we do is just click on
the instrument hold shift and go to the
last effect that's on the instrument
channel click to highlight all of them
and press command g that'll group them
all together and then once again we
click on this little circle icon that'll
bring up the ability to click on the
save icon and we can save this
instrument
and just hit enter and now whenever we
want to use this base sound we can just
hit command shift t which makes a new
midi track and then we can literally
just drag this base onto it
and it'll bring it up exactly the way
that we saved it once again super
convenient huge time saver let's say
that you open a new project and you want
to find out where are all these
instruments being saved well if you go
to the left menu here where it says
instruments just click on that click on
the little arrow by instrument rack here
and scroll down and all of your
instruments will be there that you saved
and for the effects you could just click
on audio effects rack click on the arrow
by utilities click on the arrow for
audio effects rack and all the pre-saved
effects will be right down here
real quick if this video is helpful or
even just entertaining to you i would
really appreciate you considering
subscribing and giving me the chance to
teach and inspire you to make the best
music that you're capable of and while
you're at it liking this video goes a
long way for helping youtube show it to
more people who need help with ableton
okay back to the tips my eighth tip is
to use sidechaining this technique was
made extremely popular through dance
music but it works on tons of different
genres even things like rock pop and hip
hop all side chaining is is a compressor
that's linked to another sound that
tells the compressor when to compress
i'm going to show you what the heck i'm
talking about and how to do it yourself
but i just want to say that this
transformed my production so much that
it caused me to go from sounding like an
amateur to sounding like i actually kind
of knew what i was doing it was a make
or break thing for me whenever i hear a
producer who doesn't use sidechaining
when they should have i cringe a little
bit inside so let me show you how to
side chain real quick so you don't cause
me or anyone else to cringe when they're
listening to your music okay here's a
really quick crash course in side
chaining first we have this synth
[Music]
and then we drag in a kick
[Music]
now the only issue with this is the kick
and the synth are both kind of clashing
so there's a way to make room for both
what you want to do is go to audio
effects dynamics and drag a compressor
onto the synth or whatever sound you're
wanting to sidechain then what you're
going to do is you're going to click on
this little arrow here it's going to
extend the compressor out you're going
to click on sidechain and you want to
route it audio from the kick boom then
you're going to want to click where it
says eq so it's grayed out you want to
turn the ratio all the way up the attack
all the way down and then click on this
little curved line here and that's just
going to make it so we can see what
we're doing the last thing you're going
to do is just play with this threshold
here now let's play that same synth
sound with a sidechain on it
[Music]
now all of a sudden whenever the kick is
playing the synth is ducking in volume
this is creating room in the mix for the
kick and the scent to live in harmony
now you can use this in rock music
alternative music indie music and it's
especially helpful for bass and drums
like if you have a kick and a bass a lot
of times those sub frequencies can
really clash a lot so what you want to
do is sidechain the bass to the kick so
whenever the kick is playing the bass
gets a little bit quieter and everything
sounds good together and for dance music
and some other styles you can kind of go
wild with the side chaining and even
route another compressor to the snare so
the kick and snare are just really
cutting through the mix and you can hear
them super clearly i would recommend
trying this out yourself it's really fun
and you can get some great sounding
effects pretty quickly my ninth tip is
to use ott to make things sound huge
warning this tip should be used
tastefully because it's easy to get
carried away ott is a preset for the
multi-band compressor in ableton and it
just makes anything you put it on sound
huge i remember when my friend kyle from
gray showed me the power of this preset
and i've used it pretty regularly since
then especially with dance music let me
show you how to use it and what it
sounds like and then you can decide if
you want to use it in your own
production or you might just think that
it's a little bit over the top for your
taste after all that's what ott stands
for over the top
anyway
moving on back into ableton okay now to
demonstrate the phenomenal cosmic power
of ott go ahead and click on dynamics
and then go to multiband dynamics click
the little arrow and drag on the ott
preset
so let's go ahead and solo this synth
and turn the side chain off this is what
it sounds like before ott
[Music]
and this is after
you might be thinking what the heck
sounds kind of weird super compressed
not really very good well there's a
couple settings that we tweak to make it
mwah chef's kiss first thing is i like
to click on these gray areas and drag
all the way down and this just makes it
so that the compressor doesn't hold on
for too long and then i'm going to hover
until i get this bracket and drag this
to the right
to turn the mids up and drag this to the

now this is before
it's like pretty decent and then with
ott
all of a sudden it's freaking huge like
i said you gotta use this sparingly but
especially for electronic music it's a
great way to make things sound awesome a
lot of times too you'll have to turn
something down after you put ott on it
with great power comes great
responsibility my 10th tip is to utilize
the different warp features for
different jobs whenever you drag a
sample into ableton or record something
you're able to warp that sound you could
speed sounds up you could slow them down
you can adjust the pitch you could
literally click and drag different parts
of a loop to customize it you can warp
things just like the name implies this
is one of the main features that makes
ableton so powerful however there are a
couple little tricks that took me
forever to learn with these warp
features that improved the quality of
the sounds i was warping and also just
made ableton way more fun for me in
general so let me show you exactly what
i mean okay so when you drag something
into ableton you can make it so that if
it's a long loop like this it
automatically makes the loop that you're
dragging in the same bpm of the song
that you're working on so for example
the song i'm working on is 120 bpm and
this loop is 122 but ableton made this
loop the same tempo as the song if we
click on the loop and we solo it you can
see here there's all these different
warp modes and there's a couple fun
little tricks we could do with these
warp modes for example on the beats mode
we can pick one of these like eighth
notes or 16th notes and change this
little arrow icon to stop and then drag
this down to kind of get a glitching
effect
this is what the sample sounds like
before
[Music]
this is what it sounds like with that
little glitching effect
we can even turn that into eighth notes
or 30 second notes
okay let's go ahead and go to complex
this is just a great general warping
mode to use and we can cut the loop in
half or make it twice as long by using
these divide and multiplication buttons
down here this is making it twice as
long
[Music]
and this is making it twice as fast
now we can make it twice as long but we
can use a different warp mode like
re-pitch and we get kind of this cool
slow effect
[Music]
this is a really good way to make
samples kind of feel like you sampled
them from vinyl or just make them sound
a little bit more old or vintage but
each of these warp modes have a unique
way that they affect the sound and i
would encourage you to experiment with
them and kind of get a feel for what
each of them sound like it's also worth
mentioning that usually for drum samples
say a kick sample a snare and certain
hi-hat sounds i just turn warp off
altogether like this because i just want
to use the original sample exactly how
it sounds and i don't want to tweak it
at all this is also great too if you're
recording vocals because when you do
warp stuff it can affect the quality and
usually the more you warp the more it
can kind of mess with the quality a
little bit that's part of the reason why
i showed you that re-pitch trick which
made it sound lower

but it also kind of keeps the quality up
